October 7, 1979: Fiction
JAILBIRD, by Kurt Vonnegut. (Delacorte/Seymour Lawrence, $9.95.) From World
War II to Watergate: one man's fumbling career.
THE DEAD ZONE, by Stephen King. (Viking, $11.95.) Johnny Smith can see the
future and no one wants to listen.
THE LAST ENCHANTMENT, by Mary Stewart. (Morrow, $11.95.) Further
adventures of King Arthur.
SOPHIE'S CHOICE, by William Styron. (Random House, $12.95.) The nature of
evil explored through the story of two doomed lovers.
PASSION PLAY, by Jerzy Kusinski. (St. Martin's Press, $10.95.) A horseman of a
certain age tours the country in search of polo opponents and pliant women.
TRIPLE, by Ken Follett. (Arbor House, $10.95.) Power play between intelligence
agents in the Middle East.
THE MATARESE CIRCLE, by Robert Ludlum. (Richard Marek, $12.50.) The top
American and Soviet agents save Western civilization.
SHADOW OF THE MOON, by M.M. Kaye. (St. Martin's Press, $12.95.) The great
Indian mutiny of 1857.
CLASS REUNION, by Rona Jaffe. (Delacorte, $9.95.) Four Radcliffe girls in the
1950's, and what happens to them between graduation and their 20th reunion.
SHIBUMI, by Trevanian. (Crown, $10.95.) Nicholai Hel, professional assassin,
takes on an international terror organization.
THERE'S NO SUCH PLACE AS FAR AWAY, by Richard Bach. (Delacorte/
Eleanor Friede, $6.95.) Homilies about love and friendship in the spirit of
"Jonathan Livingston Seagull."
THE THIRD WORLD WAR: August 1985, by General Sir John Hackett and Other
Top-ranking NATO Generals and Advisors. (Macmillian, $12.95.) A history of the
global war to come.
TINSEL, by William Goldman. (Delacorte, $10.95.) Under the tinsel of Hollywood
lies tinsel.
WAR AND REMEMBRANCE, by Herman Wouk. (Little, Brown, $15.) The Henry
family of "The Winds of War" during World War II.
A WOMAN OF SUBSTANCE, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $12.95.)
Self-made woman tycoon vs. her children.
October 7, 1979
Non-Fiction
THE COMPLETE SCARSDALE MEDICAL DIET, by Herman Tarnower, M.D. and
Samm Sinclair Baker. (Rawson, Wade, $7.95.) A plan to lose up to 20 pounds in
14 days.
CRUEL SHOES, by Steve Martin. (Putnam's, $8.95.) Zany satire by a young
television comedian.
HOW TO PROSPER DURING THE COMING BAD YEARS, by Howard J. Ruff.
(Times Books, $8.95.) Personal investment guide.
THE PRITIKIN PROGRAM, by Nathan Pritikin with Patrick M. McGrady, Jr.
(Grosset & Dunlap, $12.95.) A prescription for health and long life.
RESTORING THE AMERICAN DREAM, by Robert J. Ringer. (Harper & Row,
$12.50.) A polemic against big government.
BROCA'S BRAIN, by Carl Sagan. (Random House, $12.95.) Reflections on the
romance of science by a leading astronomer and geophysicist.
THE MEDUSA AND THE SNAIL, by Lewis Thomas.  (Viking, $8.95.) Essays by a
biology watcher.
THE GREAT SHARK HUNT, by Hunter S. Thompson. (Summit Books, $14.95.)
Ray, iconoclastic "new journalism" from the druggy and desperate 1960's and
ENERGY FUTURE, edited by Robert Stobaugh and Daniel Yergin. (Random
House, $12.95.) Conservation and solar energy are the solution, say the Harvard
Business School experts.
THE POWERS THAT BE, by David Halberstam. (Knopf, $15.) Four news empires
-- The Los Angeles Times, The Washington Post, Time Inc, and CBS.
THE WHITE ALBUM, by Joan Didion. (Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) Astringent
essays about the decline and fall of the 60's.
THE BRONX ZOO, by Sparky Lyle and Peter Golenbock. (Crown, $8.95.) A
behind-the-scenes look at the temperamental Yankees by their former star
reliever.
I'M DANCING AS FAST AS I CAN, by Barbara Gordon. (Harper & Row, $8.95.)
Autobiography of a successful TV producer whose life suddenly collapses.
QUEST FOR THE BEST, by Stanley Marcus. (Viking, $8.95.) A behind-the-scenes
look at the temperamental Yankees by their former star reliever.
